content: restackedKate“Wage labor is not natural. It was forced on workers with the help of enclosure and crackdowns on the poor, laws against vagrancy, harsh penalties for crimes against property, and the subordination of women to unpaid social reproduction.[1] It is a key component of the capitalist class system.”Kyle LeMieux7dWage labor has become so ingrained in our social consciousness that it is like wallpaper. We can think about changing or modifying the color or pattern, but no one really thinks about doing away with the wallpaper altogether.But wage labor is not natural. It was forced on workers with the help of enclosure and crackdowns on the poor, laws against vagrancy, harsh penalties for crimes against property, and the subordination of women to unpaid social reproduction.[1] It is a key component of the capitalist class system.Ryan Ward53

content: restackedErica Lucast StonestreetSep 1An ongoing theme of my newsletter could be summed up as “individualist vs. relational mindsets.” As I’ve been writing new things and rewriting old things, however, I’m realizing that individualism as such is maybe not as much a problem as a patriarchal hijaking of individualism. content: restackedAdam WalkerAug 28It is time for academics to acknowledge that the humanities are shifting territory. Attacked by the very institutions that shelter them, the humanities (the studies of art, literature, and language) are embattled from within. But beyond the walls of the university, they are enjoying a new life. Where the universities have failed, non-academic readers and self-learners (the class of individuals Samuel Taylor Coleridge called the “clerisy”) are committing themselves to the life of the mind. content: Aug 29We want to better work conditions in order to buy ourselves leisure time to do the “things we will”, the things we love to do. But as David Graeber taught us, may he rest in power, most of our jobs are bullshit jobs. So why do we do it, why improve work that is meaningless if not harmful to us? It is a compelling argument for work-resistance and anti-work.411

content: restackedBirgit / Mrs.BimakoAug 22Reading this, I felt both seen and challenged. Mona writes of age, hair, and menopause as things culture shames us with — and flips them into power. It’s fierce, it’s raw, and it asks us to rethink what we’ve been taught to fear in women. Worth every word… as usual.FEMINIST GIANTOld, Unfeminine, Unreliable 21
